subject: Another Month Rushes By
event:
February is almost upon us.  Damn.  Where does the time go?

Time for more odds and ends...

There's a new interview up online about HUNTER'S RUN.  Jeff Vandermeer questioned me, Gardner Dozois, and Daniel Abraham about the project.  You can check it out at

http://www.omnivoracious.com/2008/01/what-do-you-get.html

HUNTER'S RUN and INSIDE STRAIGHT are both on sale at your favorite local bookstore, by the way, so run down and snatch up some copies... if you haven't done so already.  No, they're not A SONG OF ICE AND FIRE, but I think they're fun on their own terms.

It's been a busy few weeks for DANCE.  I have been working on a Dany chapter and a Bran chapter.  (The Bran chapters remain incredibly hard to write, for what it's worth, and this one is no different).  For a change of pace, I have also been working on the third Dunk & Egg, "The Mystery Knight," which will eventually be a part of WARRIORS.

Oh, and the Giants are going to the SuperBowl.  What, I mentioned that?  Are you sure?

Speaking of WARRIORS, some of our writers have already delivered.  We have SF stories from Joe Haldeman and Robert Silverberg on hand, and a terrific Viking saga by Cecilia Holland.  (Anyone who likes good historical fiction should check out Holland's novels, she's produced a great body of work).

Bobby Fischer died.  Fischer was always a little nuts, but during the past few decades his amusing eccentricities bloomed into full-blown lunacy, and he became a crazed delusional hatemonger.  I suppose that just goes to show how close the line is between genius and madness.  (The parallels between Fischer and the other great American chess champion, Paul Morphy, are oddly spooky.  Morphy was a meteor as well, and also went nuts by the end).  His personal tragedy aside, however, Fischer may well have been the greatest chessplayer who ever lived, and his great games will long be played, replayed, and studied.  Like books, they are works of art, and like books they will outlive him.  While I never met Fischer, he had a major impact on my own life too... but that's a story for another day.

The Dark Sword miniatures have been selling up a storm, by the way, and we will soon be starting work on the second set.  Ten figures, as before: six named characters, and four more generic "troop types."  Only this time we're going to let my readers vote on which characters they'd like to see Tom Meier bring to life.  Watch this space for more details.  And if you haven't grabbed the first set yet, it's not too late.  Order off the Dark Sword website at

http://darkswordminiatures.com/

LET'S GO GIANTS!

comments.article: I thought I'd been following your blog fairly closely, but don't recall seeing an announcement of your two-volume collection of short stories. Picked them up last weekend and have been thoroughly enjoying myself. It's nice to have a copy of 'Song For Lya' that not so fragile I can't loan it out.

comments.upictitle: Stop drooling at my pic!!!!: Author pose
comments.article: I just read song for Lya this weekend as I arrived early at a pagan wedding. I have so far told 4 people about the story but not the ending.

LET'S GO PATRIOTS!!!

...

Hope the work for Dance keeps moving!

I'd just like to thank you for working so diligently on all things. While it is difficult to cope with the idea that Dance may not be in my hands for another year or so, I can suppress greed for the greater good :)

Reading 'The Black Company' right now by fellow St. Louisan (well, he lives there, so it counts!) Glen Cook. It may fall short in detail, but is a fun story.

Good luck!
comments.subject: Thank you

comments.article:
Hmmm.... you can't just drop a bomb like "While I never met Fischer, he had a major impact on my own life too..." and taunt us with a story for another day! Now its 1:00am and I'm not going to sleep. I'm going to be wondering what the heck you meant by that.

Damn!

comments.upictitle: Souffl√© Girl Wannabe: Saxon - Made of Win
comments.article:
Hoorah for more Dany and more Bran!

I got up Inside Straight from Amazon and started reading it today -- so far, it's wonderful -- as good as the original novels (I've been a fan since the first one). It's very strange having such a shiny new hardback in my hand though. I still remember picking up the first novels as paperbacks in a seedy little bookstore inside Penn Station to read on my commute to and from NYC. The new one is so posh!

Almost February! Yay!  I am hoping to see you at Page One Books in Albuquerque, twin infants willing.  I recently learned my snooty brother-in-law is fond of your writings as well.  Finally, a writer we can agree on.

comments.upictitle: J.A.C.K. Inc.  Super Secret Ninja Force: chiburi
comments.article:
Yay Giants!

Bobby Fischer was a big name when I was in the high school and college chess club. It was too bad about his later mental issues.

For a change of pace, I have also been working on the third Dunk & Egg, "The Mystery Knight," which will eventually be a part of WARRIORS.

OMG. *squeals* Am I the only one who is more exited on this than ADWD? I adore Dunk and Egg.

IIRC, someone in the ASoIaF forums said something about the title being The Mystery Knight. Hmmm....

comments.upictitle: Paul Wickham: Knight in shining armour
comments.article: No indeed your not, their my favorites as well so I share your exitement.
comments.subject: Dunk and Egg

comments.upictitle: bronxelf (The NYC Chamber of Commerce in Chucks.): winter 2014
comments.article:
While I never met Fischer, he had a major impact on my own life too...

Same here, and it will take a mighty long time for me to get over/wrap my head around the fact that he's gone.

NY?... really?!

Well, I just finished re-reading Feast for Crows, and for a change of scenery, picked up The Paper Chase by John Jay Osborn, Jr. Hunter's Run was next on my list and I cannot wait. I hope it does well!
Good luck in the Big Game George.  I'd love to see the G men upset the evil Patriots.

Glad to hear your projects are going well. As for Fischer, I'm sad for what he could have been, rather than what he became. At the risk of voicing an unpopular opinion, I find it sad that he wasted his genius on chess instead of doing something more useful. I mean, sure, there was the deal with the Russian chess player and all, but that's a rather small accomplishment considering what might have happened if he'd applied himself to science (He'd have made an amazing computer scientist), or medicine, or art, or writing instead of pushing pieces around on a board. It's a shame that he became such an antisemite and hate monger. That's not the best legacy to leave behind. He had a powerful mind, but often those with his sort of hyper-logical intellect can't really understand people. They think too much and understand too little. Too much logic, no empathy.

I'm rooting for the Giants, too. The Patriots and their fans would be insufferable if they win the Super Bowl.

I dunno, I'm with George on this one: I think a brilliant chess game is as much a work of art as a great novel or beautiful sculpture. It's destined to be remembered and studied for years to come. Also, when he beat Spazzky for the title, no American had been world champion in a century. Winning was a powerful statement for Cold-War America. People will know Bobby Fischer's name for generations, as much as any artist can hope for.
comments.subject: Art

comments.article:
Mr. Martin,

I am sure that I am not the only one that appreciates all of your hard work getting each chapter to the point where you think that they are good enough, if not perfect. We all love the finished product, and know that it is always worth the wait. Please take all the time you need on the difficult chapters.

Besides, there are plenty of books out there to keep us busy while we wait. I need to pick up the second half of Dreamsongs when I am done with the PK Dick shorts that I am reading now.

Take care, and by the way...

GO PATRIOTS :)
comments.subject: difficult chapters

comments.upictitle: in search of a clever byline: ETC - Vonnegut
comments.article: I hadn't heard about Fischer's death. One of my favorite movies is Searching for Bobby Fischer, and it is sad he didn't have parents like Josh did.
I'm a poor chess player, but my dad was a huge fan of Bobby Fischer's chess, despite the man's personal...issues. The world has lost a brilliant mind.
comments.subject: Bobby Fischer

Just bought both Dreamsongs and Hunter's Run to hold me over. I will get to them when I'm done with TG's Confessor. Have you read it? Just curious.

I love the fact that all year all you heard about from the NFC was Cowboys and Packers. Then comes the Giants and knocks em both out of the playoffs. Good show! However, thats all for them.

P-A-T-S Pats! Pats! Pats!

comments.upictitle: Polyester Bride: one who got away
comments.article:
I have no doubt the Bran chapters are hard to write, but they are some of my favorites. I never for a minute doubt that I'm reading the thoughts of an 8-9 year old boy. It's like that with all the characters - they all have a different voice, but I think it's especially pronounced with Bran.

And there's no way NY can win! (Of course, my boyfriend is originally from Boston - I have to say that. And my team, Buffalo, may as well not exist!)

George: After getting updates on Bran and Egg, I'm really wishing I'd had breakfast this morning. If you introduce a character named "Bacon", I'm done for.

Or "Sectioned Half-Grapefruit", but he'd need to be a villain.
comments.subject: I'm hungry.

comments.article:
Been looking for a spot to post my thoughts on Hunter's Run, and at last a post from Mr. Martin that mentions it. I bought the book as a Featured Selection at the Science Fiction Book Club, and my, oh my, what a blast it was, vindicating the small leap I'd taken when I gave another copy as a gift, before I'd even read mine.

The authors make us aware that Ramon is a deeply flawed character from the getgo, but there's always a certain charming transparent transparency to him that somehow makes him likable, even before he takes the crack at absolution.

So you've got a pretty classic antihero, you got 2 different kinds of space aliens, you got a chupacabra (I swear to God), and you got lots of cursin', especially in Spanish.

It's great, there's nothing not to like.

What has kind of surprised me is that there's been so little notice of the book on Mr. Martin's site. If any other author had collaborated with Gardner Dozois on a novel, and it would be plastered top and center on the front page of their website. But here, because its not ASOIAF, it's barely mentioned.

Weird.

Anyway, anyone who's on the fence about whether or not to pick up the thing, here's a note tipping you in the right direction.
comments.subject: Hunter's Run

comments.article: Very much looking forward to the next batch of figures. The first set was just amazing, but seeing Tom Meier sculpt children is going to be great.

Saw this linked from ESPN earlier:


http://www.eastvalleytribune.com/story/107441


In case you don't want to/can't read it just now, summary: Grey Ruegamer, backup and sometime starting center/guard, castrates sheep in his spare time. Using only his teeth.


I know the Super Bowl media frenzy brings out some weird stuff, but man... some reporter was working overtime to get that one.
comments.subject: Strangest Giants story yet...

comments.article:
Well, there's no doubting that Fischer was a great player, very possibly the greatest Yankee ever to say "check mate." But my vote for Greatest of All Time has to go to Gary Kasparov. Highest-rated player in history, world champion for many years, beat an IBM mainframe...

Also, though it has no bearing on chess: while Bobby Fischer became a vitriolic hatemonger after retiring, Kasparov now works to unseat Vladimir Putin and bring real democracy to Russia. Equally insane, but much cooler ;)

Congrats on a productive few weeks, and here's to a great Superbowl this weekend.
comments.subject: Greatest Ever

comments.article:
"Greatest ever" discussions are always fun, but of course the issue can never be settled.

Kasparov is an admirable fellow in many ways, and a fine player, but I still think Fischer in his prime would have crushed him. All other things being equal, I am not even sure I'd put Kasparov in my top five. After Fischer, I'd have to go with Morphy, Capablance, Lasker... and maybe, just for the romance of it, Marshall or Tal or Keres.

I also insist that Johnny Unitas was the greatest quarterback of all time, Lawrence Taylor the greatest defensive player, Gale Sayers the greatest running back (though you can make a case for Jim Brown), Babe Ruth the greatest slugger, Sandy Koufax the greatest pitcher, and...

... well, this could go on quite a while.

My standard for these "greatest ever" choices, by the way, does not involve crunching numbers and statistics, but rather weighing the question, "If you had one game of X to play, and the fate of all mankind depended on it, who would you want to bet the world on?"
comments.subject: Re: Greatest Ever

comments.article:
